article.description: Iciss Tillis had 22 points and 10 rebounds, and top-ranked Duke set a school scoring record in a 128-53 victory Friday night over Howard in a first-round game.
article.headline: Duke rips Howard to open its own tournament
article.linkText: Top-ranked Duke racks up school-record 128 points
article.story:
DURHAM, N.C. (AP) -- A power blackout in the area wasn't enough to stop Duke or the 15th annual Duke Women's Basketball Classic.

Iciss Tillis had 22 points and 10 rebounds, and top-ranked Duke set a school scoring record in a 128-53 victory Friday night over Howard in a first-round game.

Freshman Mistie Bass scored 19 points, and Alana Beard had 16 points and eight assists as seven Blue Devils reached double figures in scoring. Duke set the previous record of 120 points in a 121-120 quadruple-overtime loss to Alabama in the 1995 NCAA Tournament.

Long Beach State holds the record for most points in a game, set in a 149-69 win against San Jose State in 1987.

The power blackout that hit hundreds of thousands in North Carolina didn't effect Duke, which has a power generator for its Durham campus.

Duke (6-0), which had a 28-0 run of more than seven minutes in the first half, will face St. Joseph's on Sunday in the championship game. St. Joseph's defeated Buffalo 68-59 Friday.

"It's really been cold,'' Tillis said as temperatures outside Cameron Indoor Stadium headed toward the teens. "The power's been out at my apartment. We got it back on about noon.

"That ended up being fun. It's always good to win.''

Tillis hit her first six shots from the floor on the way to 15 first-half points as Duke charged a 60-23 halftime lead.

Bass scored 10 of her 12 first-half points during the 28-point run that broke the game open.

"I didn't want to get too nervous about starting my first game, so I tried to make like was I coming into the game off the bench,'' Bass said. "I wanted to be calm. I wanted to take what came to me and not rush too much.''

Duke scored 49 points off 29 Howard turnovers. The Blue Devils' reserves scored 58 points -- led by freshman Brooke Smith's 14 points. Lindsey Harding, Jessica Foley and Wynter Whitley each added 12.

"I thought we did a great job passing the ball,'' said coach Gail Goestenkors, who slept in her office Thursday night after she lost power at her house. "I thought we stayed focused most of the game.''
 
Asia Petty led Howard (0-6) with 18 points and was the only Bison in double figures.

"There's nothing they lack,'' Howard coach Cathy Parsons said. "I applaud my team for the effort they gave, because they never gave up. It was evident we gave our best shot, but it was just a situation where we were out-manned.''

Howard shot 18-for-63 from the floor.
